articles.headline: In Speedy Embrace of Herschel Walker, Republicans Make Familiar Political Bargain
articles.snippet: While the Georgia Senate candidate denied a report that he paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, his Republican allies looked past the claims toward November.
articles.abstract: While the Georgia Senate candidate denied a report that he paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, his Republican allies looked past the claims toward November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Herschel Walker walked into the First Baptist Church of Atlanta on Tuesday with his Senate campaign in turmoil. A day earlier, an ex-girlfriend said he had paid for her to have an abortion, despite his public opposition to the procedure. His son slammed him on social media as a liar.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maya King and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Elon Musk Suggests Buying Twitter at His Original Price
articles.snippet: The billionaire’s surprise move came months after he tried to back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.
articles.abstract: The billionaire’s surprise move came months after he tried to back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The monthslong battle over Elon Musk’s bid to buy Twitter has been massive in scale and drama. One of the tech industry’s biggest deals in recent years, it has captured the public’s imagination, with cinematic twists that have been closely followed even by people who have never written a tweet.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Lauren Hirsch and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Economists Nervously Eye the Bank of England’s Market Rescue
articles.snippet: The Bank of England stepped in to save a critical market this week. Economists say it was necessary but also worry about the precedent.
articles.abstract: The Bank of England stepped in to save a critical market this week. Economists say it was necessary but also worry about the precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Bank of England announced last week that it would buy bonds in unlimited quantities in an effort to stabilize the market for U.K. government debt, economists agreed it was probably a necessary move to prevent a cataclysmic financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Hospital System to Refund Poor Patients Who Were Entitled to Free Care
articles.snippet: Providence began reaching out to more than 700 patients after The Times contacted the hospital system about its billing and debt-collection practices.
articles.abstract: Providence began reaching out to more than 700 patients after The Times contacted the hospital system about its billing and debt-collection practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the country’s largest nonprofit hospital chains, Providence, will refund payments made by more than 700 low-income patients who were wrongly charged for medical care that should have been free.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: U.S. National Debt Tops $31 Trillion for First Time
articles.snippet: America’s borrowing binge has long been viewed as sustainable because of historically low interest rates. But as rates rise, the nation’s fiscal woes are getting worse.
articles.abstract: America’s borrowing binge has long been viewed as sustainable because of historically low interest rates. But as rates rise, the nation’s fiscal woes are getting worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s gross national debt exceeded $31 trillion for the first time on Tuesday, a grim financial milestone that arrived just as the nation’s long-term fiscal picture has darkened amid rising interest rates.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Ukraine Expels Some Russian Troops in South, Expanding Campaign
articles.snippet: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
articles.abstract: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
articles.lead_paragraph: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Fresh from victories in Ukraine’s northeast and east, the Ukrainian military on Tuesday expelled Russian forces from a town in the south, a sign that its tactic of attacking in several places at once has left its adversaries off balance and losing ground.

articles.headline: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rents are skyrocketing, luxury hotels and grimy hostels don’t have beds to spare. And on the dusty, sunny streets of Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan, bands of young migrants, nearly all men, wander aimlessly, dazed at their world turned upside down — and their hasty, self-imposed exile to a poor, remote country that few could previously place on a map.

articles.headline: In Rebuke to West, OPEC and Russia Aim to Raise Oil Prices With Big Supply Cut
articles.snippet: Led by Saudi Arabia, the oil cartel OPEC Plus pledged to reduce output by two million barrels a day.
articles.abstract: Led by Saudi Arabia, the oil cartel OPEC Plus pledged to reduce output by two million barrels a day.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and Russia, acting as leaders of the OPEC Plus energy cartel, agreed on Wednesday to their first large production cut in more than two years in a bid to raise prices, countering efforts by the United States and Europe to choke off the enormous revenue that Moscow reaps from the sale of crude.

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Will Be a Wild Ride
articles.snippet: His deal to buy the company is back on. Here are six predictions about Twitter under Musk’s control, if it happens.
articles.abstract: His deal to buy the company is back on. Here are six predictions about Twitter under Musk’s control, if it happens.

articles.headline: ‘Defund the S.E.C.’ Becomes a Rallying Cry on Trump’s Social Media Site
articles.snippet: The nation’s top securities regulator has been investigating the Trump SPAC deal for a year. Some small investors are upset.
articles.abstract: The nation’s top securities regulator has been investigating the Trump SPAC deal for a year. Some small investors are upset.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is corrupt. The S.E.C. is politically motivated. Defund the S.E.C.

articles.headline: After Mar-a-Lago Search, Talk of ‘Civil War’ Is Flaring Online
articles.snippet: Mentions in Twitter posts on the right have spiked during major political news events, and experts worry the overheated language will spread as the midterm elections draw near.
articles.abstract: Mentions in Twitter posts on the right have spiked during major political news events, and experts worry the overheated language will spread as the midterm elections draw near.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after the F.B.I. searched Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida for classified documents, online researchers zeroed in on a worrying trend.
articles.byline: By Ken Bensinger and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: U.S. Aims to Turn Taiwan Into Giant Weapons Depot
articles.snippet: Officials say Taiwan needs to become a “porcupine” with enough weapons to hold out if the Chinese military blockades and invades it, even if Washington decides to send troops.
articles.abstract: Officials say Taiwan needs to become a “porcupine” with enough weapons to hold out if the Chinese military blockades and invades it, even if Washington decides to send troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials are intensifying efforts to build a giant stockpile of weapons in Taiwan after studying recent naval and air force exercises by the Chinese military around the island, according to current and former officials.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and John Ismay

articles.headline: A Strong Dollar Is Wreaking Havoc on Emerging Markets. A Debt Crisis Could Be Next.
articles.snippet: Low-income countries, like Ghana and Pakistan, were already struggling during the pandemic. The dollar’s strength is adding to their woes.
articles.abstract: Low-income countries, like Ghana and Pakistan, were already struggling during the pandemic. The dollar’s strength is adding to their woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The average household in Ghana is paying two-thirds more than it did last year for diesel, flour and other necessities. In Egypt, wheat is so expensive that the government has fallen half a billion dollars short of its budget for a bread subsidy it provides to its citizens. And Sri Lanka, already struggling to control a political crisis, is running out of fuel, food and medical supplies.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Isabella Simonetti
